title: Front Brake Master Cylinder - Removal

body.body: Make sure the motorcycle is stabilised and adequately supported.
Do not support the motorcycle on any ancillary component, the exhaust system or any other non structural parts of the motorcycle frame.
A correctly supported motorcycle will help prevent it from falling.
An unstable motorcycle may fall resulting in motorcycle damage, serious injury or death.
Notice - Do not spill brake fluid
To prevent paint damage, do not spill brake fluid onto any area of the bodywork.
Spilled brake fluid will damage paintwork.
Front Master Cyl Remove - LJ2; LK2
To drain the fluid from the master cylinder, attach a tube to the right hand caliper bleed screw.
Loosen the bleed screw and allow the fluid to drain into a suitable container. Operate the brake lever until all fluid has been expelled.
Note the setting of the brake lever adjuster to make sure it is returned to the same position when the overhaul operation is complete.
Remove the nut and pivot bolt from the brake lever and remove the lever.
When you disconnect the brake hose from the master cylinder it is necessary to keep the open end of the hose above the handlebars.
Allowing the brake hose to fall below the handlebar height will allow an excessive amount of air to enter into the brake system.
Trapped air may cause the brake lever to feel spongy and contribute to reduced braking efficiency.
Remove the banjo bolt and disconnect the brake hose from the master cylinder.
Note the position of the brake light switch and bracket for installation.
Remove the fixing that attaches the front brake light switch and bracket to the front master cylinder.
Remove the two clamp fixings from the front brake master cylinder and remove the master cylinder.

search: Front Brake Master Cylinder - Removal
Make sure the motorcycle is stabilised and adequately supported.
Do not support the motorcycle on any ancillary component, the exhaust system or any other non structural parts of the motorcycle frame.
A correctly supported motorcycle will help prevent it from falling.
An unstable motorcycle may fall resulting in motorcycle damage, serious injury or death.
Perform the following operations:
Seat - Removal
Battery - Removal
To prevent paint damage, do not spill brake fluid onto any area of the bodywork.
Spilled brake fluid will damage paintwork.
To drain the fluid from the master cylinder, attach a tube to the right hand caliper bleed screw.
Loosen the bleed screw and allow the fluid to drain into a suitable container. Operate the brake lever until all fluid has been expelled.
Tighten the bleed screw.
Note the setting of the brake lever adjuster to make sure it is returned to the same position when the overhaul operation is complete.
Remove the nut and pivot bolt from the brake lever and remove the lever.
When you disconnect the brake hose from the master cylinder it is necessary to keep the open end of the hose above the handlebars.
Allowing the brake hose to fall below the handlebar height will allow an excessive amount of air to enter into the brake system.
Trapped air may cause the brake lever to feel spongy and contribute to reduced braking efficiency.
Remove the banjo bolt and disconnect the brake hose from the master cylinder.
Discard the sealing washers.
Note the position of the brake light switch and bracket for installation.
Remove the fixing that attaches the front brake light switch and bracket to the front master cylinder.
Brake light switch
Bracket
Fixing
Remove the two clamp fixings from the front brake master cylinder and remove the master cylinder.
